questions.question: Question 1: Which malarial parasite has the shortest incubation period?
questions.explanation: Plasmodium falciparum has the shortest incubation period of 12 days.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient from a hilly area was diagnosed with malaria. Which vector is most likely 
responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Anopheles fluviatilis is the vector for transmitting malaria in hilly areas, forests and forest fringes. Vector 
Area Anopheles stephensi 
Urban Anopheles culicifacies 
Rural Anopheles fluviatilis 
Hilly areas and forests

questions.question: Question 3: Individuals with Duffy negative RBCs are resistant to:
questions.explanation: People with Duffy negative RBCs are resistant to P.vivax. Resistance to P.falciparum is seen in: • Individuals with sickle cell trait • Neonates, as fetal hemoglobin suppresses the development of P. falciparum

questions.question: Question 4: Which is the most sensitive index of recent transmission of malaria?
questions.explanation:
The infant parasite rate is regarded as the most sensitive index for recent transmission of malaria 
in a locality. It is defined as the % of infants showing malarial parasites in their blood films. The transmission 
of malaria is considered absent if the infant parasite rate is zero for 3 consecutive years in a 
locality (even though the Anopheline vectors responsible for the previous transmission may 
remain).

questions.question:
Question 5: In a town with a population of 1,00,000, a total of 50,000 slides were examined for malaria. 
Among these, 100 cases of malaria were confirmed. What is the annual parasite incidence of 
this town?
questions.explanation:
The annual parasite incidence of this town (API) is 1. API = Confirmed cases in a year x 1000 273 
Sold by @itachibot Population under surveillance In this scenario, API = 100 x 1000/100000 = 1 API is based on the number of slide-confirmed cases that are found through active and passive 
surveillance. It is a measure of malaria incidence in a community and helps in determining the 
burden of the disease. Areas with API  2 / 1000 population are classified as high-risk areas and 
are eligible for vector control. Note: The number of slides examined is used to determine the annual blood examination rate 
(ABER).

questions.question:
Question 6: Which parameter is used to measure the operational efficiency of the National Vector Borne 
Disease Control Programme?
questions.explanation:
The annual blood examination rate (ABER) is used to measure the operational efficiency of the 
National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP).

questions.question:
Question 7: A 44-year-old woman from Assam presented with fever and chills recurring every 48 hours. 
On examination, she was conscious, oriented, and febrile. CBC, LFT, and RFT were normal. 
Peripheral smear revealed the following. What is the drug of choice? 267 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing crescent-shaped gametocytes are suggestive 
of uncomplicated falciparum malaria. As this woman is from a North-Eastern state, the drug 
regimen of choice is ACT-AL (artemisinin combination therapy): • Artemether (20mg) • Lumefantrine (120mg) This regimen is followed in the North-Eastern states of India due to documented resistance 
to sulphadoxine-pyrimethamine in these areas. ACT-AL is contraindicated in: • 1st trimester of pregnancy • Children < 5 kg

questions.question:
Question 8: A 23-year-old pregnant woman at 11 weeks of gestation was diagnosed with falciparum 
malaria. What is the drug of choice?
questions.explanation: Quinine is the drug of choice for falciparum malaria during 1st trimester of pregnancy. The treatment of falciparum malaria during pregnancy is as follows: • 1st trimester - quinine • 2nd and 3rd trimester - ACT-AL in North-Eastern states and ACT-SP in other states

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following patients with malaria can be treated with primaquine?

options.a: A 24-year-old pregnant woman at 30 weeks of gestation
options.b: A 10-year-old boy diagnosed with G6PD deficiency
options.c: A 40-year-old woman recently treated for a flare-up of SLE
options.d: A 60-year-old man who had a myocardial infarction 4 months ago

questions.explanation:
Cardiac disease is not a contraindication for the use of primaquine. It is contraindicated in: 274 
Sold by @itachibot • Infants • Pregnant and lactating women • Patients with G6PD deficiency • Patients at risk of developing granulocytopenia: • Systemic diseases including active RA and SLE • Drugs that cause hemolysis or bone marrow depression

questions.question: Question 10: What is the dose of mefloquine given for chemoprophylaxis of malaria?
questions.explanation:
Mefloquine 250 mg weekly is given for chemoprophylaxis against malaria in adults. It should be 
administered 2-3 weeks before travelling. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for travellers from non-endemic areas and as a short term 
measure for soldiers, police and labour forces serving in highly endemic areas. It should be 
complemented by personal protection and vector control. The following drugs are used for malaria chemoprophylaxis: • Chloroquine - 300 mg/week • Proguanil - 200mg/day • Mefloquine - 250mg/week • Doxycycline - 100mg/day Mefloquine is contraindicated in cases with a history of convulsions, neuropsychiatric problems 
and cardiac conditions.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the most important strategy for the control of malaria in endemic areas?
questions.explanation:
Vector control is the most important strategy to control malaria in endemic areas. Proper 
measures should be taken to kill both adult mosquitoes and larvae.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following was a component of the Roll back malaria programme?

options.c: Development of larvivorous fish for eradication of larvae

questions.explanation:
Ensuring proper and expanded use of insecticide-treated mosquito nets was a component of the 
Roll Back Malaria (RBM) programme. The other components of the RBM initiative included: • Strengthening the health system to ensure better delivery of health care • Ensuring adequate access to basic health care and training of health workers • Encouraging the development of more effective and new anti-malaria drugs 275 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which sequence of infection poses the highest risk of dengue hemorrhagic fever?
questions.explanation:
The DENV-1 --> DENV-2 sequence of infection is associated with the highest risk of dengue 
hemorrhagic fever (DHF). Multiple infections with different serotypes of the dengue virus lead to severe forms of dengue 
such as DHF/DSS. The first infection probably sensitizes the patient, while the second infection 
with a different serotype appears to produce immunological catastrophe. • DENV-1 --> DENV-2 - 500-fold risk (compared to primary infection alone) • DENV-3 --> DENV-2 - 150-fold risk • DENV-4 --> DENV-2 - 50-fold risk

questions.question:
Question 14: 269 
Sold by @itachibot What is the extrinsic incubation period of the dengue virus?
questions.explanation:
The extrinsic incubation period of the dengue virus is 8-10 days. This refers to the period 
necessary for the development of the disease agent in the arthropod host. Aedes mosquitoes become infective when they feed on infected patients from 1 day before onset of 
illness to the 5th day (viremia stage) of illness. After 8-10 days of extrinsic incubation of the virus 
in a mosquito, Aedes becomes infective and can transmit the infection. Higher 
temperature results in shortening of the extrinsic incubation period, allowing mosquitoes to 
remain infectious for a longer duration.

questions.question: Question 15: What is the cornerstone of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs?
questions.explanation:
The primary modality of treatment in patients with dengue with warning signs is IV fluids. The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage resulting in intravascular volume depletion and 
thereby shock. Warning signs in dengue include: • Abdominal pain or tenderness • Persistent vomiting • Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion) • Mucosal bleeding • Lethargy or restlessness • Hepatomegaly >2 cm • Increase in hematocrit concurrent with a rapid decrease in platelet count Inpatient management is advised to all patients of dengue with warning signs. The management 
of dengue includes: • IV crystalloids - mainstay of treatment 276 
Sold by @itachibot • Platelet transfusion - severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm3) and active bleeding FFP and cryoglobulins are not the preferred for treatment in dengue.

questions.question:
Question 16: In patients with dengue fever, platelets should be transfused if the platelet count falls below 
which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Prophylactic platelet transfusion in dengue is to be initiated when the platelet count is 
<10,000/cu.mm. Indications for platelet transfusion in dengue are as follows: • Platelet count <10,000/cu.mm • Prolonged shock with coagulopathy • Systemic massive bleeding

questions.question: Question 17: When can a patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock be discharged?

options.a: No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol

questions.explanation: A patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock can be discharged after the return of appetite. Criteria for the discharge of patients recovering from dengue: • Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretic drugs • Platelet count >50,000/cu.mm • Return of appetite • Adequate urine output • Visible clinical improvement • Minimum of 2-3 days after recovery from shock • No respiratory distress from pleural effusion or ascites

questions.question:
Question 18: 270 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is a WHO-approved dengue vaccine for individuals seropositive for 
dengue virus?
questions.explanation:
Dengvaxia is a WHO-approved vaccine for individuals seropositive for dengue virus. It is currently 
licensed in 20 countries. A pre-vaccination screening strategy must be adopted so that only dengue-seropositive individuals 
are vaccinated. It is indicated for individuals between 9 to 16 years. It is given in 3 doses, 6 
months apart. Booster doses are not required. However, it carries an increased risk of severe dengue in those who experience their first natural 
dengue infection after vaccination (seronegative individuals). Note: TV003, a live, attenuated, tetravalent dengue vaccine is currently in Phase-3 trials. It has 
shown efficacy in promoting immunity in both seropositive and seronegative individuals between 
2-59 years of age. 277 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: The prepatent period in lymphatic filariasis is the time interval between:

options.a: Invasion of infective larvae and blockage of lymphatics
options.b: Inoculation of infective larvae and detection of microfilaria
options.c: Ingestion of microfilaria and development of third stage larva
options.d: Inoculation of infective larvae and maturation into adult worm

questions.explanation:
The prepatent period in lymphatic filariasis is the time interval between inoculation of the 
infective larvae and the first appearance of detectable microfilaria. The clinical incubation period is the time interval from the invasion of infective larvae and the 
development of clinical manifestations. It is usually 8-16 months.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 44-year-old man presented with high-grade fever, chills, and pain in his groin area. 
Examination revealed reddish streaks over his lower limbs and bilateral non-pitting edema to 
the level of the knee. Swelling and tenderness in his scrotum was also noted. To diagnose the 
condition, when will you draw blood from the patient?
questions.explanation:
This patient has features of lymphangitis, lymphedema, and epididymo-orchitis, which are 
suggestive of acute filariasis. Blood must be drawn between 10 pm to 2 am. This is because the 
maximum density of microfilaria are present in the peripheral blood at this time.

questions.question: Question 21: Which is the most sensitive method to detect low-density microfilaremia in blood?
questions.explanation:
The most sensitive method to detect low-density microfilaremia in the blood is by membrane filter 
concentration. The thick film is the most commonly used method for epidemiological assessment. The DEC 
provocative test is used to induce microfilaria to appear in the blood in the daytime.

questions.question: Question 22: What is the dose of diethylcarbamazine for the treatment of Bancroftian filariasis?

options.a: Nibbling by an infected animal on abraded skin
options.c: Direct contact of infected saliva with the mucosa
options.d: Ingestion of raw meat of infected animal

questions.explanation:
The dose of diethylcarbamazine (DEC) for treatment of Bancroftian filariasis is 6 mg/kg/day orally 
for 12 days. Medicated common salt with 1-4g DEC/kg is a special form of mass treatment, particularly in 
endemic areas. By this method, very low doses of DEC are given over a long period of time. 278 
Sold by @itachibot Zoonotic Infections - Viral
